title: minister blames vladimir putin salisbury
story: NewsSecurity Minister Ben Wallace says Vladimir Putin is 'ultimately' responsible for the Salisbury Novichok attackBen Wallace said the Russian President was to blame because â€œit is his government that controls, funds and directsâ€ the GRUShare&nbspByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent08:26, 6 SEP 2018Updated10:20, 6 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/politics/video/security-minister-blames-vladimir-putin-13200396,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailVladimir Putin bears ultimate responsibility for the Salisbury Novichok attack a Government minister has said.  Security Minister Ben Wallace said the Russian President was to blame ultimately because â€œit is his government that controls, funds and directsâ€ the GRU intelligence service blamed for the nerve agent poisoning.  His comments go further than Theresa May's assertion that the attack was almost certainly also approved outside the GRU at a senior level of the Russian state. Mr Wallace told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: I don't think that anyone can ever say that Mr Putin isn't in control of his state. The GRU is, without doubt, not rogue, it is led, linked to both the senior members of the Russian general staff and the defence minister and, through that, into the Kremlin and the president's office.  The two men alleged to have been behind the March nerve agent poisoning - Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov - have been identified by the UK as members of the GRU, Russia's military intelligence service. Prosecutors deem it futile to apply to Russia for the extradition of the two men, but a European Arrest Warrant has been obtained and the authorities are also seeking the assistance of Interpol.  Mr Wallace said the UK would use whatever means we have within the law and our capabilities to push back the Russian malign activity. Asked whether there would be retaliation for Russia's activities, particularly in cyber space, Mr Wallace said: We do all the time, but we retaliate in our way. We are not the Russians, we don't adopt the sort of thuggish, destructive and aggressive behaviour that we have seen. We choose to challenge the Russians in both the overt and the covert space, within the rule of law and in a sophisticated way. As a permanent member of the Security Council, Russia will be represented at Thursday's meeting - and called on by Britain to update members on progress in the Salisbury investigation - alongside UK allies such as the US and France. Mrs May has been in contact with US President Donald Trump and other leaders as she attempts to build an international alliance in support of her stance.

title: theresa promises resolve over salisbury
story: NewsopinionTheresa May promises resolve over Salisbury attack - but she should have also shown contritionThe Prime Minister's delivery today needed to be good - she had a lot of sins to hideShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics20:28, 5 SEP 2018NewsopinionPrime Minister Theresa May updates MPs in the House of Commons, London after the CPS issued European Arrest Warrants for the extradition of the two Russian Nationals "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa Mayâ€™s statement to MPs today was praised for its authoritative tone and steely sense of purpose. This was, some said, the Prime Minister at her best. Her delivery needed to be good - she had a lot of sins to hide. Just over the two yearsâ€™ ago Mrs May had also faced MPs when Home Secretary to deliver a statement on the inquest into the murder of Alexander Litvinenko in 2006. Like the Skripals, Litvinenko had been poisoned  by two Russian agents â€œprobablyâ€ acting on the orders of Vladimir Putin. First, it should be noted that Mrs May had tried to block a full public inquiry into this killing on British soil.  In a letter to the Coroner Sir Robert Owen she cited â€œinternational relationsâ€ as a reason for the Governmentâ€™s opposition - words which implied she did not want to upset the Putin administration. It was only after a tireless campaign by Mr Litvinenkoâ€™s widow, Marina, that the Cameron government relented and agreed to hold the inquiry. Mrs Mayâ€™s response to the final report in January 2016 is enlightening. Three times she was asked by Conservative and Labour MPs to introduce a Magnitsky Act in response to the murder. This is a US law introduced in 2012 that allows the US Government to freeze the assets and ban the entry of Russians suspected of human rights abuses. Three times Mrs May rejected calls for a UK version of this act, telling MPs: â€œWe already have powers that are at least as robust, if not more so, than the powers in the Magnitsky Act.â€ Today in the Commons she boasted the Government was now bringing in the Magnitsky Act as part of a raft of measures taken in response to the Salisbury attack. Many believe she should have acted sooner.  In a telling exchange in 2016 she was asked by former Brexit Secretary David Davis, then as now a backbencher, to impose travel sanctions on leading figures in the Putin regime and expel Russian intelligence officers from London. Mrs May replied the Government had â€œalready taken a number of measuresâ€ and refused the invitation to take further action. Perhaps then, as now, Mrs May was worried about the health of the Conservative Party finances which have benefited from donations from wealthy Russians.

title: biggest hornets europe spotted uk
story: NewsBiggest hornets in Europe spotted in the UK - here's what can happen if they sting youThe sting is said to be very painful and anyone stung by these insects is advised to seek medical attentionShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJeff ReinesDanya BazaraaNews Reporter21:09, 5 SEP 2018Updated00:41, 6 SEP 2018NewsThe large, wasp-like insect that was spotted in Newton Abbot, Devon "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe largest hornet native to Europe has been spotted in parts of the UK - and the insect packs a punch when it stings. Its sting is so powerful it can send muscles into spasms and angered hornets can squirt venom into the eyes of enemies. Hornets were seen feasting on wasps near Goonhavern, between Truro and Newquay, Cornwall on August 27. Stephen Jull took a picture while he was with his friend Sarah near some woodland in an unpopulated area. Mr Jull, from Camborne, sent the photo to Cornwall Live and said the insect was one of several measuring up to 50mm . He said: It was one of several individuals all about 40 to 50mm in length. All were mild-mannered and feasting on insects including wasps.  Meanwhile, over the border in Devon, another one was photographed in Newton Abbot by a Paignton resident. The image shows the insect is about the same size as a &pound2 coin, measuring about 3cm in length. The resident was concerned it may have been one of the invasive Asian hornets which have been widely reported this year. But after Cornwall Live contacted an insect expert to find out exactly what the vicious looking critter was, she confirmed it was in fact a European hornet.  Louisa Bartlett, head keeper at Combe Martin Wildlife and Dinosaur Park, said: This is, in fact, a European hornet , which is part of the wasp family . Although they seem big and scary, they are in fact less likely to sting compared to the common wasp . They can range in size from 2-5cm in length and usually nest in holes in trees. European hornets are known to feed on large insects but can also strip off bark from trees to access the sap.  They tend to sting only when they are stepped on or grabbed, but generally avoid conflict. The sting is said to be very painful and anyone stung by these insects is advised to seek medical attention. Rare cases can also be serious, with some casualties displaying symptoms including tingling at the site of the sting, as well as headaches and shortness of breath.

story: NewsBride finds 'fit and healthy' groom dead in bed in honeymoon suite just hours after weddingDanny Emsley, 37, was found by his distraught new wife Clare after she returned from their wedding party at the Woodhall Spa in Linton near Wetherby, West YorksShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNatalie Evans06:41, 6 SEP 2018Updated08:49, 6 SEP 2018NewsDanny Emsley, 37, was found dead in his honeymoon suite just hours after his wedding"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA distraught bride found her groom dead in their honeymoon suite just hours after they tied the knot. Danny Emsley, 37, is believed to have gone to bed around 11.30pm on his wedding night on August 17. New wife Clare, 35, went to check on him an hour or so later and he was 'fine' so she returned to the party until around 1.30am, according to The Sun. She returned to the room with her mum, who helped her out of her wedding dress before leaving. But when bride Clare went to climb into bed, she found something was seriously wrong and ran from the room screaming for help, accidentally locking herself out.  Friends and family had to break down the door of the suite at the upmarket Woodhall Spa in Linton near Wetherby, West Yorks, where the couple married just 12 hours earlier. A friend told the newspaper: They called 999 and tried CPR but it was too late. Window cleaner Danny, who has a son from a previous relationship, has been described as 'fit and healthy' by friends.   Heartbroken Clare paid tribute to Danny, her partner of seven years, on Facebook . She wrote: Friday was the best day of my life, where I got to marry the best, most bluntly honest, funniest, kindest and most loving man I've ever met. We had a perfect day full of family, friends, love and laughter - we couldn't have asked for a better day. The magic ran out at the end of the night and my beautiful Danny was cruelly ripped from my life. There is a hole in my heart that can never be filled. I just don't know how I'll ever cope without you my fabulous husband.

title: dad who wore size 6xl
story: NewsDad who wore size 6XL clothes loses 10st after trip to fish and chip shop changed his lifeJohn Boland weighed 28st and wore size 6XL clothes when he first met his wife back in 2001Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience EditorRachel Tompkins18:22, 5 SEP 2018Updated07:07, 6 SEP 2018NewsJohn started gaining weight when he was very young "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNat Boland used to secretly cry to her mother-in-law about her husband's John's weight. Even though he wasn't particularly fussed about losing weight, the people who cared about him the most were terrified of the potential health risks. When Nat, 40, met John in 2001 he weighed 28st and wore size 6XL clothes. The couple fell in love and married in 2005, and two years later they became a little family when baby George was born.  But Nat was extremely worried about her husband's weight, and didn't know what to do about it. She said: I fell in love with him regardless of his size. For as long as I can remember John talked about losing weight but he was never serious or ready for it. Me and John's mum were secretly upset, emotional and worried about John's weight a lot. We often cried to each other about it but didn't know what we could do.  But then one night seven years ago, John popped out to get fish and chips and his life changed forever. When he pulled up outside the chippy carrying &pound10 to buy his family some dinner, he spotted a sign for Slimming World. Instead of going into the shop, he went into the meeting and enrolled with the weightloss programme. John, who weighed a whopping 26st at the time, decided to keep his decision a secret, telling only Nat, his mum Avril and his auntie Maureen what he was doing. Nat said: I knew that it was down to John to make it work but once he explained what he needed to be eating with Slimming world I got on board with it, getting the right shopping in, making Slimming World meals, and making sure the kids' treats were out of sight.  John cut out all takeaway food but chocolate was his real weakness so at Easter 2014 he ate about 20,000 calories of Easter Eggs and then went cold turkey and didn't touch chocolate ever again. In the first month John lost 4lbs, but in the following months he really got to grips with Slimming World, losing a stone in the second month and 10lbs the next. By the following Christmas John had lost an incredible six stones and the Christmas after his weight loss was up to ten stones. In 2012 the couple welcomed their second child, a beautiful little girl called Elsie, and John had dropped to an impressive 16st 2lb. He decided it was time to take up exercise, and quickly built up his fitness by going to spinning classes and playing football.  He also started training for triathlons and more recently has taken up ballroom dancing. Now, John is the healthiest he's ever been, and can keep up with George, 10, and Elsie, six. Seven weeks ago he had a tummy tuck to remove 3.5lbs of excess skin.

title: inside two star 60 night
story: NewsNovichok poisoning: Inside the two-star Â£60-a-night London hotel where Russian suspects plotted their attackEXCLUSIVE: As Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov checked in they would have smirked at the irony of the large Health and Safety poster on the wall behind the tiny front deskShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndy LinesMatthew YoungAmy-Clare Martin21:06, 5 SEP 2018Updated10:03, 6 SEP 2018NewsAlexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov checked into the hotel before their trip to Salisbury"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHere inside the Novichok killersâ€™ lair is where they made final preparations for their deadly trip to Salisbury. In this dingy two star hotel the Russian pair spent two nights putting finishing touches to their shocking plan. As Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov checked in they would have smirked at the irony of the large Health and Safety poster on the wall behind the tiny front desk. Little did the receptionist know his new guests were actually carrying one of the most deadly poisons on the planet.  Using a cheap green biro they signed the register like all other guests. If they wanted to remain anonymous for as long as possible this was the perfect place to choose. Rooms cost between &pound60 and &pound74 a night and guests are allowed to pay in cash.  The City Stay Hotel sits on busy Bow Road, in east London, and no-one cares who slips in and out. Police found traces of Novichok here when they finally discovered the Russiansâ€™ hideout.  And the owner has clearly gone to huge attempts to ensure there is no danger for current guests. The whole building has been freshly painted in a light yellow. Pots of paint prop up the doors to allow fresh air into the hotel. Even the carpets are new.  The entire establishment has been scrubbed clean from top to bottom following the Russian hitmenâ€™s stay. The couple would have been offered the &pound4.90 breakfast or they could help themselves to the continental for free in a basement room.  â€œBut please clean all your plates and cutlery away when you have finished,â€ said the receptionist under the eagle eye of three politan police officers. â€œThatâ€™s the one thing we would ask.â€  The breakfast room is in the basement down a narrow set of stairs. It is dark with a small kitchen and an large array of cereals. The bedrooms are fairly spartan - with many looking out over the noisy A12 outside. An Enteprise rent-a-car parking lot is across the road and Docklands Light Railway trains trundle past every few minutes. The shared bathrooms are basic to say the least. The showers are small but the toilets clean. Each room has a fan, an iron and a spare sheet.  The manager of the hotel, who declined to give his name, read out a statement to the press. He said: â€œThe City Stay Hotel in Bow Road is open for business as usual. â€œWe are fully supporting the police investigation. â€œWe are reassured that the police and Public Health England have confirmed very clearly that there is no health risk whatsoever to our guests or our staff. â€œWe are receiving a lot of media attention and we would kindly ask that you allow our staff and guests to go about their business unhindered.â€ But the five police officers who were in and around the hotel yesterday showed that things are unlikely to be the same again. And itâ€™s the ultimate irony the two hitmen were able to tune in to Channel 135 in their room â€“ where they could find Russia Today.  Locals were stunned the Russian suspects chose the modest City Stay Hotel on Bow Road in east London as their choice of venue. Two pubs sit within 100 yards either side of it, The Little Driver and The Bow Bells. And within 200 yards is a functioning police station and magistratesâ€™ court. A Texaco garage is opposite, a closed up cafe nearby and a couple of takeaways. There are few amenities to speak of and the pair could easily have flown under the radar. One local worker said: â€œItâ€™s really bizarre to come here to stay. â€œThereâ€™s not much around. I think thatâ€™s why they chose it. No one would think of here.â€ Another said it was mainly used as a through-road to get to nearby Stratford, which boast cafes, restaurants, pubs and the Olympic Park.  â€œIâ€™d say itâ€™s quite rough round here, weâ€™ve had a lot of acid attacks and stabbings, and itâ€™s a bad area for drugs,â€ said Ellie Smith, 22. â€œPeople would usually go to Stratford as thereâ€™s not much here, itâ€™s a place you pass through.â€ Abdul Musabbir, who works in the Bow Church DLR station kiosk, which is directly next to the hotel, said the area has remained unchanged in the past decade aside from a rise in stabbings and drug dealings. â€œIt is mostly tourists who stay in that hotel, but Iâ€™ve never seen anything there that seems untoward,â€ he added. Nobody at local pubs, takeaways, shops or cafes recognised the pictures of Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov. A barmaid at The Little Driver boozer said: â€œWhy would you come all the way from Russia to stay on the Bow Road? â€œIt makes no sense.

story: NewsInternational netball player, 27, had headaches on holiday and died just two weeks later from brain tumourInternational netball player Catherine Roberts, from Blackwood, South Wales, started suffering from headaches while on holiday in New Zealand and died just two weeks after arriving home to the UKShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill11:24, 6 SEP 2018NewsInternational netball player Catherine Roberts died of a brain tumour two weeks after experiencing headaches on holiday "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA superfit sportswoman died aged just 27 after being diagnosed with a brain tumour while on holiday. International netball player Catherine Roberts was travelling around New Zealand when she started suffering from headaches. She then went to see a doctor - and a scan revealed a lump on her brain. Catherine's mum - also called Catherine - flew out to New Zealand to join her daughter and they flew back to Britain together. But on her return doctors told her she was too ill for treatment, and tragically Catherine died just two weeks after landing back in the UK.  Catherine was with her fianc&eacutee Bryony Powell, also 27, and believed she had an iron deficiency when she began to suffer from headaches. Heartbroken Bryony said: She was very healthy and active so it was not normal for her to have a headache. They thought she was low on iron then a few days later we were on a bike ride and she became really confused. That was the first major sign that something was wrong.â€ Catherine, of Blackwood, South Wales, had played netball for Wales - and was described as fit and healthy when she set off on the dream trip. Catherine underwent surgery in New Zealand but was told she suffered from glioblastoma - an extremely aggressive form of brain cancer.  Bryony said: Where the tumour was located is the personality part of the brain and while in New Zealand she hadnâ€™t cried, and she was quite an emotional person. She just said it was because she was having a great time, in hindsight that was the only symptom she had. Catherine was fit and healthy, the symptoms were things that people wouldnâ€™t necessarily checked. She was tired, had headaches, confusion and a slight change in personality. Bryony wants people to now get checked as soon as they notice a change in their own symptoms.  She said: Itâ€™s really hard to process what happened and to be without her every day. The family is just devastated, we all are. We are trying to get each other through. It was tough. She was such a positive person, we never thought the worst would happen. We got engaged and we were inseparable. It is really hard to be without her.  Friends have now launched a netball tournament in memory of Catherine, of Blackwood, South Wales, which will raise money for The Brain Tumour Charity. Together with other friends they have raised more than &pound3,000 in Catherine's name since she died in May. Tournament organiser Vicki Randall said: We wanted to something for her and she would have liked a tournament.

title: lavish lifestyle mad dog gangster
story: NewsLavish lifestyle of 'Mad Dog' gangster who splashed ill-gotten gains on luxury cars and expensive holidaysCarlington Grant, known as 'Mad Dog', has been put behind bars for 26 years for his role as gang leader in a gun supplying businessShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTony LarnerAmber Hicks09:52, 6 SEP 2018Updated09:54, 6 SEP 2018NewsGrant posed with fancy cars before his gang's deadly trade was exposed "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father-of-nine known as 'Mad Dog' splashed his ill-gotten gains on luxury cars and expensive holidays before his lethal business came crashing down and put him behind bars. Carlington Grant, 41, and partner Khiana Lewis, 34, flaunted their wealth by posing for pictures on lavish trips abroad - including Jamaica - and in front of fancy cars.  But their deadly trade converting blank-firing pistols into lethal weapons, which earned them about &pound150,000, was soon exposed by police and came back to bite them, reports Birmingham Mail .  Grant was the head of a firearms supply network which saw harmless handguns brought into the UK from France before being transformed into working guns. The weapons were shipped and picked up in Cornwall.  This week, Grant, from Wolverhampton, was jailed for 26 years. While Lewis, from Brierley Hill in the West Midlands, was sentenced to 17 years. Police say the crooked Black Country couple paid for their lavish lifestyle, including trips to Jamaica, from their gun dealing. At Birmingham Crown Court on Wednesday, the pair and a third defendant were sentenced after being convicted of conspiring to sell prohibited weapons and ammunition following a three-week trial. The gang's middleman, Jermaine Dornan, 30, of Bilson, received a nine-year jail term. He was also sentenced for dealing in cannabis. The group's activities came to light in August 2016 when two of the converted guns were recovered during a covert operation by West Midlands Police.  The guns were in a shoe box and were handed over in a supermarket car park. All of the men involved in this transfer were caught on police surveillance and jailed for a total of 45 years. Serial numbers on the guns led officers to the firm in France â€“ where such firearms can be legally bought â€“ which had dispatched them as part of a larger shipment just days earlier to an address in Cornwall. A review of mobile phone data led officers to Grant and Lewis. Officers discovered the pair had made four trips to Cornwall to collect the guns before storing and converting them at a unit on an industrial estate. It is understood that Grant passed the two converted guns to the men in a meeting arranged by Dornan before the rest of the consignment was intercepted by police.  Police raided the West Bromwich industrial unit in April last year and found two firearms hidden under car bonnets, plus a large bag of ammunition in ious stages of conversion. Lewisâ€™ fingerprints were found on the ammunition packaging. And in May last year another of Grantâ€™s converted pistols was dropped during an armed raid on a carpet shop. Grant had tried to remove the serial number, but ballistic scientists from the National Ballistics Intelligence Service  were able to apply a chemical technique to recover the number which was then matched to an order from France that had been collected by Grant and Lewis. Both Grant and Dornan were arrested during simultaneous armed police raids last December, while Lewis was detained in January this year at Gatwick Airport following a holiday to Jamaica. A stash of drugs was recovered from Dornanâ€™s flat which he initially claimed was in preparation for his 30th birthday party, but later admitted drug dealing.  At court, Grant said he simply joined Lewis on day trips to Cornwall and believed she was collecting beauty products for an Internet business. But Lewisâ€™ defence barrister rubbished his claim, saying Grant spent a matter of minutes in Cornwall on each visit and hardly had enough time to buy a Cornish pasty, let alone go to the seaside, and was instead visiting purely to collect the guns. Speaking after the trio's conviction, Detective Constable Rory Juss said Grant and Lewis had paid &pound7,370 for 43 blank-firing guns and 1,160 blank-firing cartridges - which would have been worth up to &pound150,000 on the black market after they'd been converted. He said the gang charged criminals between &pound1,500 to &pound3,500 for each converted weapon. Det Con Juss said although they had no way of knowing how many of the 40 or so remaining guns were still on the streets, they were confident the supply chain had been disrupted.

title: mets famous flying squad celebrates
story: NewsAs Met's famous flying squad celebrates 100 years, bosses warn they use old school ways to nick high-tech criminalsThe elite officers of â€œThe Sweeneyâ€ remain crooksâ€™ most feared adversaries â€“ and as the Metâ€™s most celebrated branch celebrates its centenary, bosses warn that will not changeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom Parry00:01, 6 SEP 2018Updated08:27, 6 SEP 2018NewsFlying Squad officers work on a case in 1984 "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor 100 years, The Flying Squad has been getting the better of Britainâ€™s most notorious villains. The elite officers of â€œThe Sweeneyâ€ remain crooksâ€™ most feared adversaries â€“ and as the Metâ€™s most celebrated branch celebrates its centenary, bosses warn that will not change. Det Chief Supt Mick Gallagher said his officers will continue using old school methods to catch high-tech crooks. The detective said: â€œWe have to remain open so that we donâ€™t resign past tactics and methods to the past. Sometimes itâ€™s often worth revisiting something that worked very successfully. â€œIt might be that we have to start re-establishing some of the older ways that we used to work and not be so heavily reliant on technology. If encryption, for example, is going to start causing a problem.â€ The London-based branch was formed as the First World War neared its end by veteran detective Frederick Wensley.   Behind the Battle of Heathrow where cops cracked gold bullion gang in spectacular debut success for The Sweeney  It initially had two horse-drawn wagons patrolling the streets with officers hiding inside, ready to pounce. It became known for action-packed take-downs of armed robbers known as a â€œpavement ambushâ€ and got the name Flying Squad because it operated across London without adhering to borough policing boundaries. The unit was immortalised when it was portrayed in gritty 1970s TV series The Sweeney, starring John Thaw and Dennis Waterman. The nickname is an abbreviation of Sweeney Todd, Cockney rhyming slang for Flying Squad. Today it has 120 officers at two main bases â€“ soon to be 141 as its remit expands to deal with kidnap. Armed robbery remains its key focus, with moped smash-and-grab raids and deliberate gas explosions of cash machines both recent trends. Much of its success has come from building up a wide network of informants. Its swooping eagle emblem is symbolic of the way its officers swoop on criminals with speed.  Many of the most dramatic raids of recent times were carried out by the squad. In 2004, its plain-clothes officers nabbed a gang at Heathrow Airport trying to steal &pound100million in gold bullion. Our exclusive front page showed a cuffed crook sat with a rueful expression, summing up his surprise at being caught. Retired Flying Squad boss Barry Phillips, who led the surveillance operation that got the arrests, said: â€œThey would have got more than &pound100million. In doing that, it drove criminal activity right down. We were watching them for a long time in a van. We were all waiting for the lorry with the bullion on board. It was months of work, developing intelligence.â€ Flying Squad officers arrested 17 of the 19 thieves responsible for the 1963 Great Train Robbery. The squad investigated the infamous 1983 Brinkâ€™s-Mat security depot robbery and the 1987 safe deposit raid in Knightsbridge.  And, in the biggest operation in Flying Squad history, it foiled a plot to steal jewels from a diamond exhibition at the Millennium Dome in 2000. In November that year, five robbers armed with smoke bombs, ammonia and a nail gun, crashed into the dome with a stolen JCB excavator and smashed through to the vault. They had planned to escape on the River Thames by using a speedboat. Some of the officers were positioned behind a dummy wall, and others were dressed as cleaners with their firearms hidden in black bin bags, or rubbish bins, along with officers in dome staff uniforms. A further 60 armed Flying Squad officers were stationed around the Thames, and 20 on the river itself, to hamper any escape attempts.

title: odd highway code loophole driving
story: AdvertorialOdd Highway Code loophole about driving a car in the dark is leaving motorists baffledBizarre rule applies in brightly-lit 30mph zones - but there's a catchShare&nbspByDave Masters09:48, 4 SEP 2018Updated09:19, 6 SEP 2018AdvertorialMost motorists won't have heard of this"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs the weather changes, there are a few things drivers need to know about their cars and driving. The law on lights is simple enough: you must use car headlights from half an hour after sunset until half an hour before sunrise. But there is a surprising exception to this rule. If you're travelling under 30mph in a brightly-lit area, you don't legally have to have them on - though you do still need your sidelights. It's an odd quirk of the law, but is it recommended? It's generally agreed that using dipped headlights at night is always the best option - making you more visible to other road users as well as improving your view of the road ahead. But if you do choose to use just your sidelights, make sure you don't fall foul of the rules - or you risk a &pound50 fine. Not a bright idea. Make sure you know the rules  It's absolutely crucial that, at all times of the year, your car has a full set of working lights.  As well as an MOT failure, driving with a faulty or damaged light could mean a fixed penalty notice, or three points on the driving licence plus a bigger fine if it goes to court .   Since 2011, it's also been a legal requirement for all new cars sold in the EU to have daytime running lights . The new UK MOT rules mean that cars registered after March 2018 will need to have these working to pass the test.  Research has shown that DRLs are likely to reduce multiple vehicle daytime accidents and fatalities by up to 6% once all vehicles are equipped.   If you don't have DRLs on your car, then it's acceptable to leave your sidelights on all the time. Many cars will automatically turn sidelights on if they have an auto mode for lights, they will also switch to dipped lights when its sensor feels it's dark enough. The law states that you need your dipped headlights on between sunset and sunrise - but there's no harm turning them on early to improve your visibility to other road users. Check your lights regularly  The best way to do this is with a friend who can confirm that the reverse and brake lights are all working. Alternatively, you can use a reflective surface like a garage door. You can check hazard/indicator lights yourself as well as the running lights and dipped/main beam settings. If you notice a bulb isn't working, then pop to Halfords - they will select and fit replacement bulbs to your car for a small fee, and there's no need to book beforehand.  For a more comprehensive check that everything is working as it should, make an appointment online or in-store for a Free Car Check . As well as a bulb check, they'll also check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up!  Don't be dazzled  As nights get earlier we all have to contend with headlights dazzling us. Remember that most rearview mirrors these days offer protection from bright lights from behind. On newer cars you'll often have an auto-dimming mirror - which means you just let it protect you from being distracted by overly-bright lights. If you find yourself struggling to see, you'll notice an off switch to disable the feature. On older cars it's common that your rear view mirror will have a small mechanical switch underneath it. Flip that and the mirror will change angle, without adjusting the view you see. This is used to stop you from being dazzled in the same way a modern electric system works.  If your car has an old manual mirror then why not upgrade to an EchoMaster Dynamic Mirror and Reversing Camera Kit  for &pound149. A reversing camera is fitted behind your number plate by a bracket. This rearview mirror also auto-dims, perfect for autumn driving! Halfords will also fit the whole system for &pound75.  Keep your car clean  A dirty car looks bad, but it might also get you in to trouble. The law states that your number plate needs to be clean and visible at all times. You also need to make sure that brake lights are clean and clearly visible.  As well as using a good car cleaner you should also make sure your windscreen and lights are clean. Use a specialist glass cleaning product like Autoglym Car Glass Polish , &pound8. You can pair that with the Demon Car Valet Pack  - priced &pound24.50  to get every part of your car shiny as new.

title: organ donation shortage children revealed
story: NewsOrgan donation shortage for children revealed as bereaved parents of kids are less likely to donateParents are more reluctant to give the go-ahead for a transplant, with just 48% of those for under- 17s agreeingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent00:01, 6 SEP 2018Updated01:11, 6 SEP 2018NewsHarry Clarke in hospital with his mum Kerrie watching over him"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA national shortage of organ donors for children has been revealed, as figures show bereaved parents of the young are less likely to agree to donate. Parents are more reluctant to give the go-ahead for a transplant, with just 48% of those for under-17s agreeing. That compares to an average of 66% of relatives of people of all ages. This means children needing an urgent heart transplant will wait two-and-a-half times as long as adults. In the past three years 46 children have died on the waiting list. Of these 30 were waiting for a heart or lung transplant. Harry Clarke, who turns eight months old during Organ Donation Week, is at Newcastleâ€™s Freeman Hospital with a heart condition.  His parents Kerrie and Rob have uprooted their lives in Birmingham to be by Harryâ€™s side while he is treated for dilated cardiomyopathy. They know that their only hope will be the parents of another child saying â€œyesâ€ to organ donation at a time of personal tragedy. Kerrie said: â€œWe would hope that family can look at it as an &shyopportunity for their heart to live on through our son. Looking at him without his wires, you wouldnâ€™t know he was ill some days. â€œUntil you go through this and see how many babies are suffering, considering organ donation &shyprobably doesnâ€™t cross your mind but itâ€™s important to have those conversations.â€ The figures are revealed by NHS Blood and Transplant to mark Organ Donation Week. For many children on the waiting list a young donor is their only hope. Hearts and lungs need to be matched by size because of the limited space inside the chest.

title: starving girl 3 survived scraps
story: NewsStarving girl, 3, survived on scraps of bread for up to FOUR DAYS after mum killed herself at homeMum-of-two Aimee Louise Evans was found dead in her bedroom in Port Talbot, south Wales, after police visited the property following concerns for her welfareShare&nbspByEstel Farell-Roig19:27, 5 SEP 2018Updated08:23, 6 SEP 2018NewsAimee Louise Evans "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA three-year-old girl was found surviving on bread and butter up to four days after her mother killed herself, an inquest has heard. Mum-of-two Aimee Louise Evans was found dead at her home on Saturday, April 7. But when police arrived at the property in Port Talbot, south Wales, they found her daughter struggling to survive. The inquest heard the 28-year-old was found hanged in a bedroom. PC Clive Morris, of South Wales Police , told the inquest in Swansea on Wednesday that Ms Evans' three-year-old daughter was also in the house and was looking unkempt.  Mr Morris said, according to Wales Online : I became increasingly aware of the three-year-old's wellbeing â€“ the child had been there for three to four days and she was unkempt. She was taken to hospital to be checked by a paediatrician. PC Morris said police believed the little girl survived by eating loaves of bread and some butter. Ms Evans' son was staying with his father at the time. PC Morris said Ms Evans had sent a text to her mum, Julie Evans, on Wednesday, April 4.  She had asked her to collect her daughter because she was ending it, to which Julie Evans replied by saying do not be daft and asking her daughter what the matter was. That was the last time the two of them spoke, PC Morris added, with Julie Evans repeatedly trying to make contact with her daughter over the following days, including visiting the property, but getting no reply. The inquest heard the single mum was last seen alive on April 3 when she went to her mum's house. She had been drinking, but wasn't drunk, and was checking the Facebook profile of a man she had been seeing on and off. PC Morris said there were no suspicious circumstances surrounding Ms Evans' death, adding that she had no history of mental health problems.  The inquest heard the mum-of-two used to drink most evenings and had been subject to domestic violence in previous relationships. PC Morris said: Her mum said Aimee was a happy, outgoing individual that showed no signs of depression. She said her children were always well cared for â€“ that they were were always clean, tidy, and well looked after. This is one of the hardest cases I have dealt with. Senior coroner Colin Phillips said the post-mortem examination report found the cause of death to be hanging with the toxicology report showing a level of 137mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood.

story: NewsJapan earthquake: Two dead, 120 injured after 6.7 magnitude tremor leaves homes engulfed in landslide in HokkaidoThe earthquake struck just after 3am local time, leaving one person dead, at least 120 injured and 32 missing after homes were buriedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByWilliam MallardNatalie Evans00:30, 6 SEP 2018Updated07:57, 6 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/world-news/video/footage-shows-cracked-roads-destroyed-13199762,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA deadly powerful earthquake has struck on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido causing a landslide. At least two people have been killed and at least 120 injured while 38 remain missing after homes were engulfed following the 6.7 magnitude tremor. A landslide along a long ridge in the rural town of Atsumi could be seen in aerial footage from public broadcaster NHK. Aerial footage showed dozens of landslides exposing barren hillsides near the town of Atsuma in southern Hokkaido, with mounds of reddish earth and fallen trees piled up at the edge of green fields. The collapsed remains of what appeared to be houses or barns were scattered about. The entire island was without power after Hokkaido Electric Power Co said it conducted an emergency shutdown of all its fossil fuel-fired power plants following the quake.  The utility said it wasn't clear when electricity would be restored to 2.95 million households. The trade and industry ministry told the utility to restart the coal-fired Tomato-Atsuma power plant within a few hours, Trade Minister Hiroshige Seko said. All trains across the island were also halted. Roof tiles and water could be seen on the floor at Hokkaido's main airport, New Chitose Airport, which would be closed for at least Thursday. New Chitose is a major tourist gateway to the island, known for its mountains, lakes and abundant farmland and seafood, and more than 200 flights and 40,000 passengers would be affected, Kyodo News Agency said. The closure comes just a couple days after Kansai Airport, an important hub for companies exporting semiconductors near Osaka, in western Japan, was shut after it was hit by Typhoon Jebi.  The quake, which struck at 3.08am local time  posed no tsunami risk, the Japan Meteorological Agency  said. The US Geological Survey said it struck some 68 km  southeast of Sapporo, Hokkaido's main city.  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, arriving at his office before 6am, told reporters his government had set up a command centre to coordinate relief and rescue. His voice sounding haggard, Abe said saving lives was his government's top priority. The Tomari Nuclear Power Station suffered a power outage but was cooling its fuel rods safely with emergency power, said Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga.  Operator Hokkaido Electric Power Co reported no radiation irregularities at the plant, which has been shut since shortly after a massive 2011 earthquake, Suga told a news conference. A fire broke out at a Mitsubishi Steel Mfg Co plant in the city of Muroran but has largely been brought under control, NHK said, quoting local officials. A row of houses could be seen slanting at odd angles, leaning against one another in one town, while roof tiles and water covered floors at New Chitose Airport.  Many schools were closed, and some 2.95 million homes were without power, NHK said. A series of smaller shocks, including one with a magnitude of 5.4, followed the initial temblor, the Meteorological Agency said. Agency official Toshiyuki Matsumori, at a early morning news conference, warned residents to take precautions for potential major aftershocks in coming days. Shinkansen bullet trains were halted in some areas of Hokkaido, NHK said. NHK Footage showed a crumbled brick wall and broken glass in a home, and quoted local police as saying some people were trapped in collapsed structures. Soldiers were shown looking for damage on a rural road that was blocked by fallen trees. Japan, situated on the Ring of Fire arc of volcanoes and oceanic trenches that partly encircles the Pacific Basin, accounts for about 20 percent of the world's earthquakes of magnitude 6 or greater.

title: sinister past novichok assassins grandfather
story: NewsSinister past of Russian Novichok assassin's 'grandfather' who was commander in Stalinâ€™s notorious â€œdeath to spiesâ€ armyAlexander Petrov grandfather Ivan Starchenko served under Stalin as a commander of SMERSH - which was also the name of the Russia spy team in James Bond classic From Russia With LoveShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByWill Stewart09:59, 6 SEP 2018Updated10:43, 6 SEP 2018NewsAlexander Petrov, left, and Ruslan Boshirov were accused of carrying out an assassination attempt on former comrade Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man believed to be the grandfather of one of the Novichok spies was a commander in Josef Stalinâ€™s notorious â€œdeath to spiesâ€ 'SMERSH' unit, it has emerged.   Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov were accused of carrying out an assassination attempt on former comrade Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in what's thought to be revenge on Skripal for secretly spying for Britain.  Although they may be aliases, after their names were released by British prosecutors yesterday reports surfaced about Petrovâ€™s 'grandfather' Ivan Starchenko. Starchenko served under Stalin as a commander of SMERSHâ€™s 31st shooting brigade during the Second World War on the First Ukrainian Front. SMERSH was set up by Stalin to root out and kill spies but it was also the fictional Soviet counter intelligence agency in James Bond, featuring in the classic From Russia with Love.  Petrovâ€™s 'grandmother' Nadezhda Moroz also worked as clerk-typist for the same rifle division and was awarded a medal For Military Merit in November 1943. The medal was awarded by Major Ivan Ivanovich Starchenko, described as the chief of the Counter-Intelligence Unit of 31st Shooting Division - the man who would become her husband. The claim from investigative reporter Sergey Kanev raises the possibility that Petrov, believed to be aged 39, is from a family of spies engaged in counter-intelligence.  Records show Starchenko was a SMERSH major at the end of the war, later becoming a state security sergeant in Stalinâ€™s counter-intelligence apparatus. He was awarded a succession of top honours including the Red Star Order, 1943, the Patriotic War Order, grade 1, 1944 and the Red Banner Order, 1945. He had been educated at the notorious NKVD spy school in Moscow, graduating in 1937 during the Stalin terror. Another military connection is that Petrov's maternal uncle 66 year old Valery Starchenko - pictured here and Ivan's son - was a paratrooper and linguist , who studied at the famous Ryazan military academy. Skripal's brother Valery, who died in a mysterious road accident two years ago, was also a paratrooper. Theresa May claimed both Petrov and Boshirov are GRU agents and that their mission to plant novichok at the Skripal family home in Salisbury would have been approved at the highest levels in the Kremlin.  There is also evidence that Petrov made a trip to London from 28 February to 5 March 2017, claimed Fontanka based in St Petersburg. With Boshirov, he also made previous trips together to Europe, according to flight records. â€œFrom September 2016 to March 2018 they visited Amsterdam, Geneva, Milan and went several times to Paris.â€ Boshirov and Petrov are known to have non biometric passports with almost identical numbers, suggesting they were issued two years ago at the same time. Petrov is believed to have been born in June or July 1979, making him 39.

title: craig easton sees irn bru as a chance for dundee united kids to get their fizz back
story: Dundee United reserve team boss Craig Easton believes Saturdayâ€™s Irn-Bru Cup clash with Alloa will be the perfect test for his young team.The Tangerines second string were on the wrong end of a 5-1 score in the Reserve League at Hearts on Monday.But Craig believes the margin of the home teamâ€™s victory was not a fair reflection on his sideâ€™s play and is viewing the weekend tie as a chance to show that.â€œWe are looking forward to the game even though it comes on the back of what wasnâ€™t a good result for us against Hearts,â€ he said.â€œIt wasnâ€™t a 5-1 performance, though. title: csaba laszlos new boys are showing some promise at dundee united
story: It remains early days so far as judging new-look Dundee United goes but there is no question Csaba Laszloâ€™s team are getting to know each other.After a sticky start to the season, there have been definite signs over the last three, unbeaten, Championship outings that the team is coming together.And the Tele takes a look and how the new men have contributed, so far.Matej RakovanAfter joining up on the same day as fellow-goalie Benjamin Siegrist, one of the big questions going into the campaign was which of the pair would get the nod. So far heâ€™s lived up to expectations and looked a strong and calming influence.Paul WatsonProbably the most low key signing, at first it seemed doubtful if the man who was a squad player at Falkirk would feature too often. With the arrival of Rachid Bouhenna, he still faces a challenge to keep his place.Christoph RabitschThe Austrian has had a robust start to his United career and a couple of rash tackles when he was already on a booking have seen him subbed to prevent the team being reduced to 10 men. The 22-year-old was publicly slapped down by Csaba for that. He appears to have taken it on board and thereâ€™s no question his ability to get in about opponents is an asset.Adam BartonCaptured from Partick Thistle just before the Betfred Cup games kicked off, the tall Englishman has added to Unitedâ€™s new-found aerial strength. Most of his appearances so far have been in midfield, so heâ€™ll face a challenge once skipper Fraser Fyvie returns from injury, but heâ€™s also been used in central defence and that versatility has given the manager more options.Fraser AirdOne of the first signings of the summer, the Canadian has added pace in the wide areas. He earned his move on the strength of performances against United for Dunfermline last term and, so far, he might just have been the best of the new bunch.Yannick LoembaThe winger was an unknown quantity who hadnâ€™t had much football in the last year or so. However, thereâ€™s been no evidence of that and heâ€™s made a lightning start to his time with United. The 28-year-old always wants on the ball and his eagerness to get forward has made him a fansâ€™ favourite.Pavol SafrankoThe loan signing from Aalborg marked his debut with an excellent goal in the win at Queen of the South and has looked the part since. Well-known to the manager from their time together in his native Slovakia, Safranko looks to be the centre-forward United have been crying out for.Craig CurranA dead leg picked up in pre-season delayed his involvement until the opening league game when Dunfermline won at Tannadice. As his fitness has improved after that injury, Curran has shown himself to be a hard worker and chipped in with a goal against Partick.

title: decision to be made on future of dundees total wipeout watersports park

title: dundee city centre butchers plans to create cafe and cookery school
story: Ambitious plans have been outlined for a cafe and cooking school at a Dundee butcher shop.Scott Brothers Butchers is hoping to adapt another level of its Nethergate store as part of a new venture.And co-owner Scott Jarron said the forthcoming opening of the V&ampA has been a factor in the decision to transform the business.Scott said the firm â€“ which has three retail premises across the city â€“ has been planning the changes for three years.He said: â€œWe are planning to turn the first floor of the business into a cafe with the meals served related to food on offer within our store.â€œWith the cooking school element, we felt we had a social responsibilty to help the next generation of youngsters to learn cooking skills.â€œWe also intend to work with local charities and schools on this to promote the benefits of healthy eating.â€œWe will need to close the store and realistically we would be starting work in February or March.â€Scott added that the plans are at a very early stage.And he explained how the opening of the V&ampA had influenced the decision to transform the business.He said: â€œThere will be a significant amount of investment in the premises â€“ within the range of Â£400,000-Â£500,000.â€œGiven the location of our business in the city centre and the imminent opening of the V&ampA, we feel there is a great opportunity to offer something different.â€Dundee-based architect Jon Frullani, who has been working on the project, described the venture as â€œexcitingâ€.He said: â€œItâ€™s great to see another use of a city centre premises that adds diversity to whatâ€™s on offer.â€

title: dundee council hopeful that observatorys main telescope could return to use
story: Progress has been made towards repairing the Mills Observatory.Earlier this year the shutter mechanism on the roof dome failed, making it unable to be opened so the main telescope could be used.Staff have been relying on smaller portable telescopes so visitors can still see the sky.After attending a meeting of the Mills Observatory Advisory Group, a Leisure and Culture Dundee spokesman said: â€œDundee City Council is looking to have an engineerâ€™s report during the next month to advise on requirements and associated costs to repair the dome.â€œIn terms of Leisure and Culture Dundeeâ€™s plans, we are looking to deliver as full a programme as possible â€“ aiming to keep our opening hours as normal for the winter season.â€Councillor Fraser Macpherson said he was anxious for repairs to be undertaken and is pleased progress is being made.He said: â€œLeisure and Culture Dundee is ensuring that as full a programme as possible is run at the observatory while repairs move forward, which is reassuring.â€œWhat is now vital is that necessary capital funding is identified so that repairs work can move forward promptly allowing the Mills Observatory to again offer a full service.â€

title: dundee have a real gem in young striker cedwyn scott says berwick boss
story: Young Dundee striker Cedwyn Scott has earned high praise after a brace on his debut for Berwick.Boss Robbie Horn was highly impressed by the teenager.His double came in a 5-3 win at Albion Rovers when he grabbed the third and fifth goals in a dramatic tie.Horn said: â€œMy research had shown that Cedwyn was a good player but he is better than I had hoped for. title: dundee people more to coffee than you think
story: When it comes to making your lattes, cappuccinos and espressos, it is not just as simple as the click of a button.Matt McDevitt, 20, started working in the hospitality industry at just 15-years-old and although he may be young in years the now barista has a wealth of experience.He moved to the City of Discovery three years ago, after working in restaurants in St Andrews, before finding a role at The Flame Tree Cafe on Exchange Street.Over the past two and half years Matt has worked hard on his barista skills and says he hopes one day he might even open a cafe of his own.Matt said: â€œI have been in the catering industry since I began working.â€œI have worked in the kitchen and front of house which has allowed me to gain a good experience of a number of roles.â€œWhen I stared working at the Flame Tree I sort of floated about and did a number of different roles before I pushed to gain a barista-type role.â€œI wanted to gain experience and learn everything I could about the industry so that perhaps in the future I can open my own place.â€œWhen working as a barista there is so much more to making coffee than just pushing a button.â€œWhen I start work between 7.30-8am, it can be hectic as you get a breakfast rush.â€œBut I have to check the grind to ensure it is not too course or too fine, I also have to see the run-time for brewing an espresso.â€œThere is a lot you need to learn about coffee that people maybe donâ€™t realise.â€When it comes to the Flame Treeâ€™s two premises, one on Exchange Street and the other on Perth Road, there are many familiar faces that Matt has gotten to know over the years.He added: â€œI love being able to talk to the regulars and get to know them.â€œIt is incredibly important in the catering industry to be able to talk to people and also get on with the team you work with.â€œWe are like a unit and whenever any of our staff members move on it is like losing a pal.â€œMaybe when I am about 50 I will move to Spain and open a really gimmicky Scottish cafe, but for now I am pretty chuffed to be working at Flame Tree.â€œI really enjoy it and I am constantly learning new things.â€

title: dundee united must win dirty games laments csaba laszlo
story: In the wake of Saturdayâ€™s 1-1 draw at Alloa, Dundee United boss Csaba Laszlo still cuts a frustrated figure.The Terrors, and Csaba, had been on a high after comfortable wins over Queen of the South and Partick Thistle saw them, seemingly, turn a corner.United controlled and managed those matches well but all their good work came undone as they laboured to a point at the Indodrill Stadium at the weekend.Csaba had spoken at the start of the season about his sideâ€™s need to start grinding out results if they want to win the Championship.And his disappointment and anger was evident as they couldnâ€™t dictate what he called a â€˜dirty gameâ€™ in Clackmannanshire.â€œIt was a dirty game but one which really, if you want to make the top league, you have to manage all the time and finish,â€ he said.â€œThis is not about dominating the game, itâ€™s about winning the game.â€œIt is clear for us that this was an artificial pitch and even it was seven, eight yards shorter than usually.â€œSo I wait for my team and itâ€™s clear, in this case, you have to circulate the ball quicker, you have to move the ball out quicker to have the possibility to move up the pitch.â€United had opened the scoring in the second half through a Paul Watson header on 71 minutes, his third goal in two games, and it could have been more.Yannick Loemba had what would have been his first strike for the Tangerines ruled out for offside and Csaba felt 18-year-old Declan Glass could have played in fellow-sub Callum Booth to put the game beyond doubt.As it transpired, the kid gave away possession and Alloa broke to win the free-kick which Iain Flannigan curled home on 82 minutes to earn the Wasps a point.It was no less than the home side deserved but Csaba couldnâ€™t help scrutinise his teamâ€™s game management.â€œWe were in front, you have just to keep the ball and keep the result,â€ he added.

title: event in dundee to showcase how your smartphone can help improve health
story: A new public awareness week in Dundee will champion the use of technology in health and shine a light on how the public can use smartphones and computers to improve their lives.Discover Digital will launch at Dundee Science Festival next month.Visitors to the science centre will be able to test gadgets that can keep them safe, see how interactions with doctors might be carried out via video-conferencing and learn about the ways technologies such as 3D printing, smart speakers and virtual reality can be used to boost health and wellbeing.The aim is to raise awareness of the support available and involve the public in shaping the range of digital healthcare technologies in the future.Health Secretary Jeane Freeman said: â€œThe Discover Digital events on October 21 are the first of their kind across the UK.&#8220The Scottish Government is committed to supporting people to better manage their own health.â€

title: ex dundee united boss ray mckinnon rubbishes judas tag after morton exit
story: He has been branded a Judas in Greenock but former Dundee United boss Ray McKinnon is adamant his decision to leave Morton for Falkirk was down to him chasing silverware not silver.McKinnon was named the Bairns boss on Friday night in a stunning switch just three months after he took over at Cappielow.It was a move that did not go down too well in Greenock, with chairman Crawford Rae releasing a statement with â€˜a tinge of resentmentâ€™ that suggested underhand tactics from Falkirk and claimed Ton would be seeking legal advice over McKinnonâ€™s departure.The local newspaper, the Greenock , was even more forceful in its reaction to his resignation.&mdash Ceres Arabs  September 2, 2018The publication depicted the 48-year-old as Judas clutching his bag of 30 pieces of silver â€“ the price the Biblical character is said to have been paid to betray Jesus.McKinnon has confessed he was startled by the force of the backlash.He said: â€œI was disappointed by it, I thought it was pretty poor. Anyone who knows me and who knows the back story wouldnâ€™t have put that in their paper.â€œIf you speak to anyone I worked with â€“ Lochee United, Brechin, Raith Rovers and Dundee United, I was loyal to everyone.â€

title: it could be all change in the dugouts as dundee united get set to face alloa again
story: It will be the same teams but it could be two different managers when Dundee United and Alloa clash in the Irn-Bru Cup at Tannadice on Saturday.The pair drew 1-1 at the Indrodrill Stradium in the Championship at the weekend with Csaba Laszlo and Jim Goodwin occupying the technical areas.As is the Tangerines policy for the Irn-Bru this term, it will be reserve team boss Craig Easton who takes charge for the coming second-round tie.And there could also be a change in the Waspsâ€™ dugout after their manager Goodwin was tipped to succeed Alan Stubbs at former club St Mirren.Stubbs was sacked by the Buddies yesterday after just nine games and a run of just one win in four Premiership outings, against bottom club Dundee, so far.If Goodwin does return to the team he has such strong links with, it could see former United favourite Paddy Connolly, his assistant at Alloa, put in charge at Tannadice.

title: no excuses for display at alloa says dundee united midfielder adam barton
story: Dundee United midfielder Adam Barton insists they can have no excuses for their poor performance at Alloa despite the tough conditions.The Terrors drew 1-1 with Jim Goodwinâ€™s side on Saturday in a game they were expected to win.The synthetic surface at the Indodrill Stadium was narrowed for Unitedâ€™s visit and the hosts made life difficult for Csaba Laszloâ€™s men throughout.Despite opening the scoring through a Paul Watson header on 71 minutes, as well as enjoying some bright spells in the second half, the Wasps were always in control.A sublime Iain Flannigan free-kick earned Alloa a well-deserved point and it couldâ€™ve been more.Barton said: â€œIf we want to win the league, these are the places youâ€™ve got to go and do the job.â€œWhat frustrates me is people on the outside, particularly the fans, who were there in good numbers on Saturday. They donâ€™t understand how difficult it is to go to places like Alloa and do what you usually do.â€œLooking at the pitch, compared to Tannadice itâ€™s completely different altogether, so you have to adjust your game. Alloa are playing there nearly every week so theyâ€™re used to it.â€œYouâ€™ve got that against you but itâ€™s not just us, itâ€™s going to be every team that goes there.â€œIt was a difficult task on Saturday but again thatâ€™s an excuse and we shouldnâ€™t have excuses.â€œWe should be going there and doing the job.â€Barton and central-midfield partner Christoph Rabitsch endured a difficult afternoon as Alloaâ€™s Allan Trouten and Steven Hetherington engaged them in a physical battle.And the 27-year-old Englishman admits they lost control of the match.â€œWe didnâ€™t control the game at all, itâ€™s as simple as that, we tried and couldnâ€™t. Itâ€™s just the way the game was,â€ he added.â€œIâ€™m sure at home it will be a completely different game but we werenâ€™t used to the conditions and the width of the pitch, so it was tough.â€œI thought we deserved a point. I donâ€™t think we deserved to win the game and fair play to them because they gave everything theyâ€™ve got.â€œWe went to Alloa knowing it was not going to be easy. We didnâ€™t underestimate them but they just played their game very well.â€œEven in midfield I drop in to get the ball and we mostly look like a back three.â€œWe couldnâ€™t do that against Alloa because it would give them a chance to press us and we were unable to do that.â€œThat was one way in which we were affected in the way we like to play but Iâ€™m sure a lot of teams will go there and struggle to play their game.â€Barton was honest in his assessment of the performance and says Unitedâ€™s players are not used to a more physical game but insists he knows theyâ€™ll need to get used to it.â€œIt turned into a bit of a scrap. We donâ€™t set up to play that kind of football and we donâ€™t have the players who do that.â€œA lot of people would say you need to be able to adapt to most games but even the best players in the world donâ€™t do the scrappy side of things. Itâ€™s just the way it is.â€œItâ€™s in your nature, you canâ€™t work on the physical side on the training pitch, you can work on being organised and having a better structure but you canâ€™t go into training and work on aggression.â€œIt just doesnâ€™t happen and if youâ€™re an aggressive person, great â€“ if youâ€™re not then youâ€™re not.â€œYou canâ€™t wake up one day and say â€˜Iâ€™m going to be aggressiveâ€™.â€œWeâ€™re not bothered about the play-offs, we want to win the league and we need to go to Alloa and win.â€

title: poll results dundee fans give clear verdict on whether neil mccann should stay as manager
story: Dundee fans have given a clear message to the board regarding the future of manager Neil McCann.The Tele yesterday ran an online poll asking fans if McCann deserves more time to turn things round after at Dens a terrible start to the season.His position as Dundee manager is coming under increased scrutiny after his side lost for the fifth match running on Saturday.The Dark Blues went down 3-1 at home to Motherwell â€“ and it could have been a lot worse.The Dee sit bottom of the table without a point and have twice been beaten by lower league opposition in the Betfred Cup.McCann is correct when he says his team had a similarly bad opening to last seasonâ€™s campaign before recovering to finish safely in ninth place.However, less than one in five supporters shared his optimism as 80% of Dundee fans who voted in our online poll called for him to be dismissed after 17 months in the hot seat.Of the 1,609 votes submitted, 1,297 believed his time was up.One of our readers wrote: &#8220His tactics and player recruitment have not been good enough.&#8220There is no passion in his players, they were second best against a Motherwell side who chased and harried for everything throughout the match.&#8220He should do the gentlemanly thing and resign and realise he is a better pundit than a manager.&#8221Just 312 people felt he deserved more time.One wrote: &#8220He is still a rookie and there are worse teams in the league.&#8221McCann has time to regroup his players during the international break before a trip to Rangers, one of his former clubs, a week on Saturday.&nbsp

title: strictly come prancing meets the first couples to take part in dundees version of strictly come dancing
story: Strictly Come Prancing â€“ Dundeeâ€™s answer to the BBC TV hit show â€“ is already shaping up to be the most talked-about charity event of the year.A dozen local couples will battle it out at a glitzy dance-off at the Apex Hotel in November in front of a panel of judges headed by celebrity style guru Gok Wan. Funds from the event will go to childrenâ€™s charity Help for Kids.Here, Jon Brady and Iqra Farooq speak to two of the couples taking part.Family friends Mark Dunlop, 46, and Kelly Leslie, 39, are going to have a challenge on their hands â€“ because they wonâ€™t dance together for the first six weeks of their training. 100vw, 376px" /Mark Dunlop and partner Kelly LeslieKelly and her family are away to Florida for three weeks, and around the time she comes back Mark heads off to Australia.So, while the pair will be going to their lessons when they can, they wonâ€™t actually dance as a couple until halfway through the preparation.Kelly, a hairdresser from Fintry, said: â€œWe both signed up after a couple of drinks. We thought it would just be a laugh but it dawned on us at the launch night how serious it was.â€œWeâ€™ve resolved to throw ourselves into it since itâ€™s for charity and weâ€™ll have fun along the way.â€Neither Mark nor Kelly are big Strictly fans, nor are they experienced at dancing.The only time they have danced together is at football dinners, as Mark plays alongside Kellyâ€™s husband Richard â€“ also a Help for Kids Ambassador â€“ at Barnhill AFC.Kelly said: â€œIâ€™m not worried about dancing in front of Gok Wan or anything but the thought of going out in front of 500 people is a bit scary.â€œBut my husband is also entering the contest â€“ Mark and I are determined to make sure we knock him out.â€Quantity surveyor Mark, from Monifieth, said: â€œI have absolutely no experience of dancing â€“ none, save for after a couple of drinks at some weddings.â€œIâ€™m quite relaxed because I think they wanted people that donâ€™t have a lot of experience.â€œBut as it gets closer and closer Iâ€™m beginning to realise itâ€™s not just something to laugh about in the pub any more â€“ after the launch night it started to feel very real.â€Mark isnâ€™t an avid Strictly fan, but says heâ€™s seen a few shows.He said: â€œI think we can almost certainly say Iâ€™ll have a new-found respect for all the dancers on the show once weâ€™ve got through it all.â€œItâ€™s going to be interesting, and a good laugh. At the end of the day, whatâ€™s the worst that could happen?â€Long-term friends Derek Miller, 41, from Letham, and Jenni MacFarlane, 43, from Ballumbie, canâ€™t wait to start practising their routine.The pair first met while working in radio in their early 20s.Fast forward to now and Derek works as a foster carer and has previously been involved in fundraising for Help for Kids â€“ the local charity that will receive funds from the event.He said: â€œI am an ambassador for the charity so I know what benefits it has for kids in the area.â€œIt is very important for us to be part of the event and we are aiming to raise as much money as we can.â€He added: â€œIâ€™m very nervous about it because I have absolutely zero dance experience apart from a Saturday night at a wedding.â€Although a newcomer to the world of dance, Derek has dedicated himself to getting in shape for the night by joining a running club in Arbroath.Jenni, who works as a senior operations manager at Openreach, said: â€œI knew I wanted to do it when Derek asked because I love Strictly.â€œI have to admit I am a bit nervous about it but I canâ€™t wait to get our training started.â€œThe size of the event is making me nervous. Iâ€™m not shy but being taken out of my comfort zone is a bit scary.â€As a Strictly fan, Jenni admitted she was in charge of organising the routine.She said: â€œWe have not picked a song to dance to yet but we are definitely going to go for something fun and upbeat â€“ but weâ€™re not telling anybody.â€œWeâ€™re in it to win it.â€She added: â€œI do not know any of the other contestants but Iâ€™m looking forward to making friends at training.â€Jenni and Derek have already started their fundraising by having their training gear sponsored.Strictly Come Prancing is being supported by the Evening , radio station Wave FM and the Overgate Shopping Centre. During the launch, the 12 couples were announced and received a video message of support from TV star Gok after posing for their first photo shoot.Tickets are on sale at eventbrite/e/strictly-come-prancing-tickets-48946935602.

title: xplore postpones planned changes to dundee buses until next year
story: Planned changes to a number of bus routes in the city have been postponed until the new year.Xplore Dundee said it was delaying its review of services, which mainly affect the West End, Charleston, Loons Road and Milnbank Road, until January.The company had previously notified Dundee City Council that the changes would come into effect from October 21.Xploreâ€™s managing director Christine McGlasson said the bus operator wanted to â€œensure we are making the best decisions to improve services for as many customers as possibleâ€.â€œWeâ€™ve taken another look at the timing of this network review in light of future plans for services in the north of the city,â€ she said.â€œTaking into account the results of our 32/33 route review in Fintry and the ongoing development in Whitfield, weâ€™re aware that routes in this area are also facing changes to ensure they are efficient and punctual.â€œRather than confuse passengers with two separate timetable reviews, we have decided to implement these all at once, in the new year.â€œWe will take this opportunity to talk to customers and community groups to ensure we are making the best decisions to improve services for as many customers as possible.â€The changes, which Xplore said would â€œimprove service punctuality and address passenger suggestionsâ€ affect the 1a/1b, 4, 5, 9/10 and 29.In some cases, it means streets will no longer have active bus stops and lose their connection to Ninewells Hospital.The plans received a mixed response when they were announced last month. West End local Linda Groat, 51, who has MS and finds walking distances difficult, said the postponement would give her time to â€œmake a good protest about itâ€.â€œIt is something I am passionate about and I am sure that there are other people in the area that are passionate about it as well,â€ said Linda, who uses the number 5 which could bypass her street come January.â€œThere are loads of people down this way and not everybody has got a car.â€œIâ€™m not asking for a full-blown service, even just a couple of buses a day.â€
